docs.title: AOD4184 (D4184) MOSFET Module — AC001
docs.text: Aliases: D4184 / AOD4184 “MOSFET relay” module (various vendors) Category: AC

docs.title: Quick Facts
docs.text:
• Type: N-channel MOSFET low-side switch (module). You put the load between LOAD and +, the module switches the ground side.
  • Logic: Accepts MCU input (3.3–5 V on most modules)
  • Current: Marketing says “50 A”, but real-world continuous is ~10 A @ 12 V without extra heatsinking due to PCB thermal limits.

docs.title: Links
docs.text: • Where to buy: AliExpress

docs.title: Typical Pinout (varies by seller)
docs.text:
• Power side: + (to supply +), LOAD (to load’s negative end), - must be connected to supply - and GND of esp
  • Control side: PWM: Connect to GPIO, GND: Connect to GND from esp.

docs.title: Wiring (ESP32 → 12 V fan example)
docs.text:
• 12 V + → + on module, 12 V − → module GND (power ground).
  • Fan + → 12 V +; fan − → LOAD on module.
  • ESP32 GPIO (e.g., GPIO 23) → PWM on module; ESP32 GND → module GND.

Remember: Load goes between LOAD and +. The module sinks current to ground (low-side).

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text: • Audible ringing with PWM: Buzz often comes from the load/PSU when you PWM in the audible band (<20 kHz). Two easy fixes: use time-proportioning (slow duty cycling) with multi-second periods (see example below) or push PWM >20 kHz.

docs.title: Code — Easiest: 5s ON, 5s OFF (ESP32 / Arduino)
docs.text:
// AC001: D4184 / AOD4184 module test — 5s ON, 5s OFF
// Wire: ESP32 GPIO 23 -> IN, GNDs common
const int RELAY_PIN = 23;

void setup() {
  pinMode(RELAY_PIN, OUTPUT);
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW); // start OFF
}

void loop() {
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, HIGH); // ON
  delay(5000);
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW);  // OFF
  delay(5000);
}

docs.title: Code - "x% power" without audible whine (slow time-proportioning)
docs.text:
// AC001: Time-proportioning control (TPC) with a long period (no audible PWM)
const int RELAY_PIN = 23;

// set desired power level (0–100)
int power_percent = 30;           // e.g., 30% average power
const unsigned long PERIOD_MS = 10000; // 10s cycle

void setup() {
  pinMode(RELAY_PIN, OUTPUT);
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW);
}

void loop() {
  unsigned long on_ms  = (PERIOD_MS * power_percent) / 100;
  unsigned long off_ms = PERIOD_MS - on_ms;

  if (on_ms > 0) {
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, HIGH);
    delay(on_ms);
  }
  if (off_ms > 0) {
    digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, LOW);
    delay(off_ms);
  }
}

docs.title: Ultra-thin Horn Speaker - AC002
docs.text: A very small 30 mm, 8 Ω, 0.5 W ultra‑thin dynamic speaker. Use it for simple beeps, prompts, or low‑volume audio in compact projects. It cannot be driven directly from an ESP32 pin — pair it with a small amplifier (e.g., LM386 or a class‑D module like PAM8302).

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: TI LM386 (amplifier)
  • Tutorial: ESP32 audio player with LM386

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Impedance: 8 Ω (8R)
  • Power rating: 0.5 W
  • Diameter: 30 mm (ultra‑thin style)
  • Leads: 2‑wire pigtail (vendor notes “P2.0 termina wire”) (Values taken from the AliExpress listing; exact SPL/response not provided.)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text: Not applicable — two wires only. Polarity is not critical for a single speaker, but keep consistent (+/–) if using multiple speakers to avoid phase issues.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Do not connect the speaker to an ESP32 GPIO directly. Use a small amplifier:

  • LM386 (simple, through‑hole; 5 V supply; class‑AB)
  • PAM8302 (efficient class‑D; 2.5–5.5 V; recommended for battery projects)

Example with LM386 (ESP32 DAC → LM386 → speaker):

  • ESP32 GPIO25 (DAC1) → 100 nF (series) → LM386 IN
  • LM386 VCC → 5 V; GND → GND
  • Gain: leave pins 1–8 open for ×20, or add 10 µF between 1–8 for higher gain (per datasheet)
  • Speaker to LM386 OUT and GND
  • Add 220 µF from OUT to speaker if using a bare IC per typical app (see datasheet)

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Never drive the speaker from a GPIO directly — you will damage the ESP32 or get inaudible output.
  • LM386 is easy but inefficient and can hiss at high gain; use PAM8302 for low‑power builds.
  • Keep leads short and twist them to reduce noise pickup.
  • This 30 mm, 0.5 W unit is for low‑volume use; don’t over‑drive.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Minimal ESP32 sketch that generates a tone via PWM (LEDC) into an amplifier input:

// ESP32 PWM beep -> feed amplifier input (LM386/PAM8302) via 0.1 uF cap
// No extra libraries required.
const int AUDIO_PIN = 25; // or another GPIO

void setup() {
  ledcSetup(0, 2000, 8);   // channel 0, 2 kHz, 8-bit
  ledcAttachPin(AUDIO_PIN, 0);
}

void beep(unsigned freq, unsigned ms) {
  ledcWriteTone(0, freq);
  delay(ms);
  ledcWriteTone(0, 0); // stop
}

void loop() {
  beep(1000, 200);  // 1 kHz beep
  delay(800);
}

For WAV/streamed audio using the ESP32 DAC and an LM386, see the linked tutorial.

docs.title: Piezo Ceramic Elements - AC003
docs.text: Thin piezoelectric brass/ceramic discs (≈27 mm Ø). They generate a voltage when flexed, so they can be used as vibration/knock sensors; driven with an AC waveform they work as a very small buzzer/sounder. Choose these when you need a quick impact/vibration input or a lightweight beeper. For vibration sensing, add a high-value load resistor and protect the ESP32 pin from voltage spikes.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: PDF (generic 27 mm piezo diaphragm; exact spec varies by seller)
  • Tutorial: Detect a Knock (piezo vibration)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
From the listing:

  • Type: Piezo elements (metal/brass + ceramic)
  • Diameter: 27 mm
  • Leads: pre‑soldered wires (varies by batch)
  • Pack size: 10 pcs
  • Typical uses: speech/music transducer, percussive sensors, drum pads

(No detailed electrical specs on the listing. See the generic datasheet above for typical resonance and capacitance of 27 mm discs.)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
Bare disc with two leads:

  • Any lead → signal
  • Other lead → GND
  • Polarity isn't important for sensing; for driving as a buzzer, apply a small AC waveform across the two leads.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Vibration (safe for ESP32 ADC):

  • Solder or clip the disc to the target surface for best sensitivity.
  • Connect one lead to an ESP32 ADC pin (e.g., GPIO34).
  • Put a 1 MΩ resistor in parallel with the disc (from ADC pin to GND) to load it and reduce spikes.
  • Add protection: two 1N4148 diodes from the ADC pin to 3V3 and GND (clamp), or a 100 kΩ series resistor plus the 1 MΩ load.
  • Share GND with the ESP32.

Simple buzzer (quiet):

  • Drive with a small‑signal AC (e.g., 2–5 kHz PWM via a series resistor ≥100 Ω). For louder output use a proper driver stage.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Piezo discs can produce large voltage spikes when hit—always use a high‑value load and clamping or series resistance to protect the ADC.
  • Very high impedance → long wires pick up noise; keep leads short or shielded for sensing.
  • Mounting strongly affects sensitivity and tone.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Read vibration on ESP32 (ADC + threshold):

// Needs no external libs. Wire disc to GPIO34 (ADC1_CH6).
// Add 1 MΩ from GPIO34 to GND, and clamp diodes or a 100 kΩ series resistor.

const int PIEZO_PIN = 34;      // ADC pin
const int THRESHOLD = 1200;    // tweak based on your hardware (0..4095 on 12‑bit ADC)
const int QUIET     = 20;      // ignore tiny noise

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  analogReadResolution(12);        // 0..4095
  analogSetPinAttenuation(PIEZO_PIN, ADC_11db); // wider range
}

void loop() {
  int v = analogRead(PIEZO_PIN);
  static uint32_t lastHit = 0;

  if (v > THRESHOLD) {
    uint32_t now = millis();
    if (now - lastHit > 50) {      // simple debounce
      Serial.printf("Knock! peak=%d\n", v);
      lastHit = now;
    }
  } else if (v > QUIET) {
    // optional: stream baseline/noise
  }
  delay(2);
}

Tiny beep (very quiet):

// WARNING: Piezo discs are capacitive. Use a series resistor (>=100 Ω).
// For real sound, drive differentially or use a driver. This is just a "click/beep".
const int PIEZO_DRV = 25;  // any PWM-capable GPIO
void setup() {
  ledcSetup(0, 4000, 10);      // 4 kHz
  ledcAttachPin(PIEZO_DRV, 0);
}
void beep(uint16_t ms=80) {
  ledcWrite(0, 512);           // ~50% duty
  delay(ms);
  ledcWrite(0, 0);
}
void loop() { beep(); delay(1000); }

docs.title: 12085 passive buzzer - AC004
docs.text:
A small passive buzzer in a 12 mm × 8.5 mm can (“12085”). Passive means it needs a square‑wave signal (PWM/LEDC) to make sound. Use it for beeps/alerts or simple melodies. The AliExpress listing mentions “42R” which typically indicates a magnetic passive buzzer (coil) rather than a piezo disc, so treat the exact type as ambiguous until verified. If it’s magnetic, include a flyback diode when switching it with a transistor; if it’s piezo, the diode is not needed.

Source: AliExpress listing 10PCS 12085 Passive Buzzer 12×8.5 mm • “42R” resistance • 3–12 V common Diameter: 12 mm • Height: 8.5 mm Notes: The listing calls it “Mini Piezo Buzzer” but also mentions “42R”, which usually indicates a magnetic buzzer (coil). Treat the exact type as ambiguous unless you verify the inside or see a + polarity mark.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: Representative 12×8.5 mm buzzer datasheet (exact model on listing not specified) — Link
  • Tutorial: ESP32 buzzer with PWM (techtutorialsx)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Form factor: Ø12 mm × 8.5 mm can (a.k.a. “12085”)
  • Type (from listing): Passive (requires AC drive / PWM)
  • Electrical (from listing): “3–12 V”, “42 Ω” (ambiguous: may indicate magnetic type)
  • Typical drive (general): 2–5 Vpp square wave at ~2 kHz (piezo) or 3–5 V square wave (magnetic)
  • Polarity: Piezo versions often have a + mark; magnetic types may be non‑polar. Verify before wiring.
  • Use cases: Beeps/alerts, UI feedback, simple melodies.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text: Two leads only: - + / SIG – drive signal (connect to transistor/driver; some piezo cans mark +). - − / GND – ground return. If no + is marked and DC resistance ≈ 42 Ω, it’s likely a magnetic passive buzzer.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Recommended (safe & loud): NPN driver (e.g., 2N2222) + ESP32 PWM

  • ESP32 GPIO → 1 kΩ → base of NPN, emitter to GND.
  • Buzzer between +5 V (or 3.3 V) and collector.
  • If magnetic buzzer, add a flyback diode (1N4148/1N5819) across the buzzer (+ to +V side).
  • If piezo, no diode is needed.
  • Share grounds between ESP32 and supply.

Quick/quiet test (not for volume): Drive directly from a GPIO with a 330–1 kΩ series resistor; works for many piezo cans but expect low volume. Avoid direct drive for magnetic 42 Ω types (may over‑current the pin).

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• The listing mixes “piezo” wording with “42R” (magnetic). Verify type before adding or omitting a flyback diode.
  • Directly powering a magnetic 42 Ω unit from a GPIO can exceed the pin’s current rating. Use a transistor.
  • For loudness, drive at or near the part’s resonant frequency (often ~2 kHz but varies by model).

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
// ESP32 (Arduino) – simple tone on a passive buzzer via LEDC PWM
// Wiring: use NPN driver; connect buzzer to +5V and NPN collector (see wiring section).

const int BUZZER_PIN = 18;   // any PWM-capable GPIO
const int LEDC_CHANNEL = 0;
const int LEDC_TIMER   = 0;

void setup() {
  ledcSetup(LEDC_CHANNEL, 2000 /* Hz */, 10 /* bits */);
  ledcAttachPin(BUZZER_PIN, LEDC_CHANNEL);

  // Play a short beep at 2 kHz
  ledcWriteTone(LEDC_CHANNEL, 2000);
  delay(200);
  ledcWriteTone(LEDC_CHANNEL, 0); // stop
  delay(300);

  // Simple 3-note pattern
  int notes[] = { 1000, 1500, 2000, 0 };  // Hz; 0 = rest
  for (int i = 0; notes[i] >= 0; ++i) {
    if (notes[i] == 0) {
      ledcWriteTone(LEDC_CHANNEL, 0);
    } else {
      ledcWriteTone(LEDC_CHANNEL, notes[i]);
    }
    delay(180);
  }
}

void loop() { /* nothing */ }

docs.title: 99-S12 smart cabinet electromagnetic lock - AC005
docs.text: Compact 12 V fail‑secure solenoid bolt used for cabinets, drawers and small doors. When powered, the bolt retracts (unlock). When unpowered, the spring pushes the bolt out (lock). Ideal when you need a simple latch you can pulse from an ESP32 via a MOSFET or relay—no position sensing built‑in.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: Similar model (Multicomp Pro MP001163) PDF — dimensions & duty‑cycle are indicative, exact values may differ from 99‑S12.
  • Tutorial: ESP32 controlling a solenoid lock (wiring + code): ESP32IO

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
Extracted from vendor listings for 99‑S12 (values vary by batch/variant):

  • Operating voltage: 12 V DC ("12 V universal")
  • Current: variants listed around 0.35 A / 0.6 A / 1.2 A (instantaneous trigger) — measure your unit
  • Pull stroke (throw): 0–4 mm
  • Pull force: at 4 mm ≥ 80 g (typ. at 0.35 A)
  • Retention: at 0 mm ≥ 120 g
  • Operating mode: power‑on = unlock; power‑off = lock (fail‑secure)
  • Duty / interval note: listing states “power on 90%, interval” — treat as intermittent duty (use short pulses)
  • Ambient: −25 °C to +80 °C; RH 45–80 %
  • Withstand voltage: AC 1000 V; Insulation resistance: 50 MΩ
  • Leads: 2‑wire pigtail
  • Life: up to 1,000,000 cycles (vendor‑stated)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text: This part is just the actuator, no PCB: - Red (+12 V) — connect to +12 V supply. - Black (GND) — connect to MOSFET/relay side to switch return to ground. (No logic pins, no addresses.)

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
ESP32 cannot drive the lock directly. Use a logic‑level N‑MOSFET or a relay module.

MOSFET option (recommended for speed/size): - 12 V + → lock red wire. - Lock black wire → DRAIN of N‑MOSFET (e.g., IRLZ44N, AOZ/AOD logic‑level types). - SOURCE → 0 V (GND). - GATE → ESP32 GPIO via ~100 Ω; add 10 kΩ gate pull‑down to GND. - Flyback diode across the lock (e.g., 1N5819/1N4007): anode to MOSFET side, cathode to +12 V. - Common ground: tie ESP32 GND to 12 V supply GND.

Relay option: ESP32 → Relay IN; relay switches 12 V to the lock. Still add a flyback diode across the coil if your relay board doesn’t have one.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Treat as intermittent duty: use short pulses (e.g., 100–500 ms) to unlock; avoid long holds or it will heat up.
  • Current varies by batch (0.35 A–1.2 A). Bench‑measure your unit and size wiring/MOSFET accordingly.
  • Always use a flyback diode; without it you risk brown‑outs or ESP32 resets.
  • Fail‑secure behavior: loses power ⇒ locks. Plan for power‑loss scenarios.

docs.title: How to use (ESP32 / Arduino)
docs.text:
Simple pulse‑to‑unlock using a MOSFET (active‑HIGH gate). No external libraries needed.

// GPIO driving a logic-level N-MOSFET gate through ~100Ω
const int LOCK_PIN = 16;  // choose any suitable GPIO

void setup() {
  pinMode(LOCK_PIN, OUTPUT);
  digitalWrite(LOCK_PIN, LOW); // ensure locked (no power to solenoid)
}

// Pulse to unlock for 200 ms
void unlockPulse(uint16_t ms = 200) {
  digitalWrite(LOCK_PIN, HIGH);  // power the solenoid => unlock
  delay(ms);
  digitalWrite(LOCK_PIN, LOW);   // remove power => lock
}

void loop() {
  // Example: unlock for 200 ms every 5 seconds
  unlockPulse(200);
  delay(5000);
}

If you use a relay module instead of a MOSFET, replace LOCK_PIN wiring accordingly (some boards are active‑LOW).

docs.title: WS2812B - AC006
docs.text: Individually addressable RGB LED in a 5050 SMD package with an integrated controller (“NeoPixel”‑compatible). Uses a single‑wire 800 kbps protocol to daisy‑chain many LEDs with 24‑bit color (GRB). Runs from ~5 V and is ideal for status lights, indicators, light bars and small animations.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: PDF
  • Tutorial: Random Nerd Tutorials

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Package: 5050 SMD, 1 LED + integrated driver per pixel.
  • Supply: Typically 5 V (electrical characteristics given for VDD=4.5–5.5 V). Absolute supply rating listed as +3.5 to +5.3 V.
  • Logic levels: DIN VIH ≥ 0.7×VDD (so at 5 V, ≥3.5 V), VIL ≤ 0.3×VDD.
  • Data rate: 800 kbps single‑wire; GRB byte order.
  • PWM scan freq: ≥ 400 Hz.
  • Chaining: signal reshaping each pixel; at 30 fps, “not less than” ~1024 pixels.
  • Timing (±150 ns): T0H≈0.4 µs, T0L≈0.85 µs, T1H≈0.8 µs, T1L≈0.45 µs; reset low ≥ 50 µs.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
• VDD — +5 V supply
  • DIN — Data in (from MCU / previous LED)
  • VSS — Ground
  • DOUT — Data out (to next LED)

Pin names and order per datasheet. Decouple each LED with a local 0.1 µF capacitor (shown as “104” in the typical circuit).

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
ESP32 → WS2812B (single LED or strip):

  • Power the LEDs from a stable 5 V rail. Tie GND (ESP32) to VSS (LED).
  • Drive DIN from an ESP32 GPIO through a ~330–470 Ω series resistor.
  • Place a large electrolytic (e.g., 470–1000 µF) across the 5 V rail near first LED to absorb inrush.
  • Level shifting: Because VIH is 0.7×VDD, a 3.3 V ESP32 output is below spec when LEDs run at 5 V. Use a proper level shifter (e.g., SN74AHCT125/74HCT14) or run the LEDs closer to 4.5 V so 3.3 V meets VIH, if your setup allows.
  • For long runs, inject 5 V power every 1–2 m and at both ends. Keep data wire short and alongside ground.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Don’t drive DIN when LEDs are unpowered (add series resistor + ensure common GND).
  • 3.3 V logic into 5 V‑powered LEDs is out‑of‑spec per VIH; many strips work but it’s not guaranteed—prefer level shifting.
  • Start‑up can draw a surge; oversize the 5 V supply and add bulk capacitance.
  • GRB color order (not RGB) is expected by default.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Arduino (ESP32) with Adafruit_NeoPixel

#include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>
#define LED_PIN  5          // pick any PWM-capable GPIO
#define LED_CNT  8          // number of pixels
Adafruit_NeoPixel strip(LED_CNT, LED_PIN, NEO_GRB + NEO_KHZ800);

void setup() {
  strip.begin();
  strip.show();             // turn off all pixels
  strip.setBrightness(64);  // 0..255
}

void loop() {
  // simple color wipe
  for (int i = 0; i < LED_CNT; i++) {
    strip.setPixelColor(i, strip.Color(255, 0, 0)); // red
    strip.show();
    delay(50);
  }
}

Libraries: Adafruit NeoPixel or FastLED (PlatformIO/Arduino Library Manager).

docs.title: Ultrasonic Nebulizer Driver - AC007
docs.text: A small driver board for ultrasonic atomizer discs (≈20 mm piezo, ~108–113 kHz). These boards create a cool visible mist by pushing water through a porous mesh at ultrasonic frequency. Use when you need quick humidification or fog effects in enclosures, incubators, props, or scent projects. These particular boards are power‑only devices (no documented control I/O); you typically switch their 5 V power from a microcontroller.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy (6‑nozzle): AliExpress
  • Where to buy (dual‑nozzle): AliExpress
  • Datasheet (transducer specs): STEMinc 20 mm / 113 kHz atomizer
  • Tutorials / build ideas:
    • Seeed Studio “Grove – Water Atomization”
    • CircuitDigest “Ultrasonic Mist Maker using ESP‑01”

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
Six‑nozzle board (from listing):

  • Supply: 5 V (USB‑C)
  • Current / Power: ~300 mA board rating; recommend ≥ 2 A 5 V supply (seller notes “Minimum 2A”)
  • Power: 2.5–3 W
  • Atomization frequency: 108 kHz ± 2 kHz
  • Modes: six‑spray / dynamic / single / multiple (mode cycling on board)
  • PCB: FR‑4, 1.2 mm
  • Module size: 65 × 30 mm; disc connector: PH2.0 to 20 mm atomizer tablets (aperture 4–5 µm)
  • Accessories: brackets + cotton wicks (per kit)

Dual‑nozzle board (from listing):

  • Power: 2–3 W, intended for USB 5 V sources
  • Operating temperature (claimed): −40 … +80 °C
  • Other details are vague in seller text; treat as a similar 5 V 108–113 kHz atomizer driver. If critical, verify with the exact board in hand.

Atomizer discs (typical 20 mm metal‑mesh):

  • Resonant frequency: ~113 kHz
  • Droplet size: ≈10 µm
  • Rated input at the disc: tens of Vp‑p driven by the board (do not drive discs directly from GPIO)
  • Example transducer specs: see “Datasheet” link above.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
These boards are usually power‑only:

  • USB‑C 5 V in (or VBUS/GND pads if provided)
  • Disc connectors (JST‑PH 2.0) to the piezo atomizer tablets

Some variants expose a push‑button to change spray modes. No documented logic‑level control pins are provided on the referenced listings.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Goal: switch the board’s 5 V power from an ESP32.

  • Provide a separate 5 V supply rated ≥ 2 A for multi‑nozzle boards. Do not power from the ESP32 or USB hub ports.
  • Switch power using one of:
  • A 5 V relay module (easy, but bulky/noisy), or
  • A high‑side P‑MOSFET load switch board rated ≥ 2–3 A (preferred for silence/efficiency).
  • Common ground between ESP32 and the 5 V supply/load switch. Keep high‑current 5 V traces short and away from the ESP32 RF.
  • Keep the atomizer away from electronics; condensation is real. Use a splash guard and route the mist upward.

Minimal wiring (P‑MOSFET switch):

  • ESP32 GPIO → gate driver/control of the load‑switch module
  • Load‑switch VIN = 5 V, VOUT → humidifier board VBUS
  • Grounds tied together

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• These boards do not accept ESP32 GPIO control directly; you must switch their 5 V.
  • Current spikes at start‑up can reset your system—use a stout 5 V supply and short wiring.
  • Moisture will corrode boards: mount vertically, add drip protection, and avoid enclosed spaces without airflow.
  • Atomizer discs are consumables; performance drops over time. Keep spare 20 mm, ~108–113 kHz discs.
  • If your board cycles “modes,” that behavior is internal; it can’t be set digitally unless your specific PCB exposes pads (not documented here).

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Example: toggle the mist with a GPIO driving a typical active‑low EN pin on a P‑channel high‑side load‑switch module. Uses only Arduino.h on an ESP32.

// ESP32: toggle a 5V load switch controlling the nebulizer board
const int MIST_EN = 15;   // connect to load-switch EN (active-low or -high varies by board)
bool activeLow = true;    // set according to your switch board

void setup() {
  pinMode(MIST_EN, OUTPUT);
  // default off
  digitalWrite(MIST_EN, activeLow ? HIGH : LOW);
}

void mistOn()  { digitalWrite(MIST_EN, activeLow ? LOW : HIGH); }
void mistOff() { digitalWrite(MIST_EN, activeLow ? HIGH : LOW); }

void loop() {
  mistOn();
  delay(10 * 1000);   // 10 s ON
  mistOff();
  delay(20 * 1000);   // 20 s OFF
}

Libraries: none (plain Arduino core). If using a relay module, drive its IN pin instead. For humidity‑based control, pair with a SHT4x/DHT22 and implement simple on/off hysteresis.

docs.title: 1-Channel Relay Module - AC008
docs.text: Single-channel relay board with optocoupler input and jumper-selectable trigger level (HIGH or LOW). Use it to safely switch mains or higher-current DC loads from an ESP32 GPIO via an isolated input stage. Typical variants are available with 5 V or 12 V coils. If you need more than one channel, use multi‑relay boards instead.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Tutorial: Random Nerd Tutorials – ESP32 Relay Module (Web Server)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Optocoupler‑isolated input stage
  • Operating voltage (coil): 5 V or 12 V (board variant)
  • Trigger: HIGH or LOW selectable via on‑board jumper
  • Indicators: Power LED and Relay status LED
  • Max load: AC 250 V / 10 A, DC 30 V / 10 A (depends on relay fitted; verify on your part)
  • Control input IN requires ≳ 4 mA drive current (from listing)
  • Output contacts: COM, NO, (NC is present on most modules even if the listing only calls out COM)

Values above were taken from the AliExpress listing. If your board has a different relay model, follow that relay's datasheet limits.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
Header / screw terminals (I/O side): - DC+ (VCC): Board power for the input/driver (5 V or 12 V version) - DC− (GND): Ground - IN: Control input from microcontroller - Jumper: Selects HIGH or LOW trigger

Relay terminals (load side): - COM: Common contact - NO: Normally‑Open (closes to COM when active) - NC: Normally‑Closed (opens from COM when active)

Some one‑channel boards expose COM/NO only; others provide COM/NO/NC.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Assuming a 5 V relay module with an ESP32:

  • Power the module DC+ = 5 V, DC− = GND from a 5 V supply. (Don’t power the relay coil from the ESP32 3.3 V pin.)
  • Connect ESP32 GND ↔ DC− (common ground).
  • Connect an ESP32 GPIO (e.g., GPIO 26) to IN.
  • Place the jumper to match your preferred trigger (LOW or HIGH).
  • Wire your load to the COM/NO/NC screw terminals as needed. For mains, break only one conductor (active/hot) and keep neutral/earth intact.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Mains safety: Treat anything on the relay terminals as high voltage. Use proper creepage/clearance and insulated enclosures. If unsure, stick to low‑voltage DC loads.
  • Active‑LOW vs ACTIVE‑HIGH: Many boards default to active‑LOW. Use the jumper to choose, and match it in code.
  • Board variants: Some modules have separate JD‑VCC/VCC pins for true opto‑isolation; this board appears to use DC+/DC− only (shared ground).
  • Contact ratings: 10 A is the maximum under ideal conditions. For inductive loads (motors, solenoids), derate and consider snubbers/RC or MOVs.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Very simple example (Arduino framework on ESP32). Adjust RELAY_ACTIVE to LOW or HIGH to match your jumper setting, and pick a free GPIO.

// 1-Channel Relay Module (optocoupler) – ESP32 example
// Requires no special libraries

const int RELAY_PIN = 26;          // choose any suitable GPIO
const int RELAY_ACTIVE = LOW;      // set to LOW or HIGH to match jumper
const int RELAY_INACTIVE = (RELAY_ACTIVE == LOW) ? HIGH : LOW;

void setup() {
  pinMode(RELAY_PIN, OUTPUT);
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, RELAY_INACTIVE);
}

void loop() {
  // Toggle the relay every 2 seconds
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, RELAY_ACTIVE);
  delay(2000);
  digitalWrite(RELAY_PIN, RELAY_INACTIVE);
  delay(2000);
}

docs.title: SG92R 90-180 Degree - AC009
docs.text: A tiny 9 g micro servo (often sold as TowerPro SG92R) widely used in hobby robotics and small mechanisms. It rotates to a commanded angle using standard servo PWM (≈50 Hz) and provides modest torque for light linkages, knobs, and flaps. Use it when you need position control (~0–180°) rather than continuous rotation.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: PDF
  • Tutorial: Random Nerd Tutorials – ESP32 Servo

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
AliExpress listing did not include a detailed table. The following are typical for SG92R; minor variations exist by vendor/batch—confirm in the datasheet or your specific listing.

  • Operating voltage: 4.8–6.0 V (5 V typical)
  • Stall torque (4.8 V): ~2.5 kg·cm
  • Speed (4.8 V): ~0.1 s / 60°
  • Mass: ~9 g
  • Dimensions (body): ≈23 × 12.2 × 27 mm
  • Gear train: POM with carbon fiber
  • Control: 50 Hz servo signal (approx. 500–2400 µs pulse range)
  • Typical current while moving: 100–300 mA; stall can reach ~650 mA

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
Color codes vary by vendor:

  • Brown/Black = GND
  • Red = +5 V
  • Orange/White = Signal (PWM)

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
• Power the servo from a separate 5 V supply able to provide ≥1 A surge per servo.
  • Tie GND of the servo supply and ESP32 GND together.
  • Connect Signal to any ESP32 GPIO that supports LEDC PWM (e.g., GPIO 18).
ESP32        SG92R
-----        -----
5V (ext)  -> +5V (red)
GND        -> GND (brown/black)
GPIO 18    -> Signal (orange/white)

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Do not power from the ESP32 3.3 V pin. Use a stable 5 V source.
  • Provide bulk decoupling (≥470 µF) near the servo connector.
  • Avoid commanding beyond physical limits (~0–180°); excessive pulse widths can strip gears.
  • Expect noise/EMI; keep signal lead short or twisted with GND.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Arduino (ESP32): Install the ESP32Servo library by Kevin Harrington (Library Manager).

#include <ESP32Servo.h>

Servo s;
const int SERVO_PIN = 18; // any PWM-capable GPIO

void setup() {
  // Use a dedicated PWM timer/channel
  ESP32PWM::allocateTimer(0);
  s.setPeriodHertz(50);          // Standard 50Hz
  s.attach(SERVO_PIN, 500, 2400); // min/max pulse (us)
  s.write(90);                   // center
}

void loop() {
  for (int a = 0; a <= 180; a += 5) { s.write(a); delay(20); }
  for (int a = 180; a >= 0; a -= 5) { s.write(a); delay(20); }
}

docs.title: 25mm Fan 12V - AC010
docs.text:
Compact 25×25×10 mm 12 V DC brushless cooling fan with a 2‑pin XH2.54 connector. Use it anywhere you need a small spot of airflow: cooling voltage regulators, MOSFET boards, small enclosures, 3D‑printed parts, or tight spaces inside projects.

This is a 12 V load, not something you can power directly from an ESP32 pin. Drive it from an external 12 V supply and switch it with a MOSFET or driver board.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: none found (generic 25 mm 12 V sleeve‑bearing fan; rely on seller specs)
  • Tutorial: Random Nerd Tutorials – ESP32 PWM with Arduino IDE

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
From seller description (typical values for this fan type):

  • Fan size: 25 × 25 × 10 mm (2510)
  • Connector: XH2.54, 2‑pin
  • Rated voltage: 12 V DC (sleeve bearing version)
  • Rated current: 0.06 A
  • Power: ≈ 0.72 W
  • Speed: ~10 000 RPM
  • Airflow: ~2.12 CFM
  • Air pressure: 0.19 inH₂O (approx.)
  • Noise: ~25.7 dBA
  • Cable length: ~150 mm
  • Bearing type: sleeve
  • Estimated life: ~35 000 h
  • Weight: ~7 g

These numbers are approximate and may vary slightly between batches. For critical designs, derate current and airflow a bit.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
This fan is a simple 2‑wire DC fan with an XH2.54‑2P connector:

  • Pin 1 – V+ (12 V DC): connect to the positive terminal of your 12 V supply.
  • Pin 2 – GND: connect to supply ground (and to ESP32 ground when controlled by it).

There are no tachometer or PWM pins on this model; speed is set purely by supply voltage (or PWM on the supply via an external switch such as a MOSFET).

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
To control the fan with an ESP32 you typically:

  1. Provide power
  2. Use a separate 12 V DC supply capable of at least 0.2–0.3 A for some margin.

  3. Do not power the fan from the ESP32 3.3 V pin.

  4. Switch the fan with a MOSFET (low‑side switching)

  5. Use an N‑channel MOSFET (e.g., logic‑level type) to switch the fan’s ground.

  6. Wiring (simplified):

    • Fan +12 V → 12 V supply +.
    • Fan GND → MOSFET Drain.
    • MOSFET Source → 12 V supply GND.
    • ESP32 PWM GPIO → MOSFET Gate (through a small resistor, e.g. 100–220 Ω).
    • Optional: 10 kΩ resistor from Gate to Source to keep the MOSFET off at boot.

  7. Protect against inductive spikes

  8. Place a flyback diode (e.g., 1N5819/1N4007) across the fan terminals:

    • Diode cathode to +12 V, anode to fan GND (MOSFET drain).

  9. Common ground

  10. Connect ESP32 GND to the 12 V supply GND so the gate drive reference is correct.

With this setup, the ESP32 only switches the MOSFET gate and never drives the fan directly.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Needs 12 V: it will not run from 3.3 V and will be weak at 5 V unless you bought a 5 V version.
  • Inductive load: always use a flyback diode and a suitable MOSFET or driver.
  • Startup current: briefly higher than 0.06 A; leave headroom on your 12 V supply.
  • Airflow direction: small arrows on the fan frame usually show airflow and rotation directions—mount accordingly.
  • Noise vs. speed: at full duty cycle it’s louder; use PWM to slow it down where possible.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Very simple example of driving the fan speed with PWM using an ESP32 and a MOSFET on pin GPIO 5.

Hardware assumptions - Fan powered from 12 V supply as described in the wiring section. - MOSFET low‑side switch on the fan’s GND, gate connected to ESP32 GPIO 5. - Common ground between 12 V supply and ESP32.

Code (Arduino IDE, uses ESP32’s LEDC PWM API):

const int FAN_PIN     = 5;   // GPIO connected to MOSFET gate
const int PWM_CHANNEL = 0;
const int PWM_FREQ    = 25000; // 25 kHz is typical for fans
const int PWM_RES     = 8;     // 0-255

void setup() {
  // Configure PWM channel
  ledcSetup(PWM_CHANNEL, PWM_FREQ, PWM_RES);
  ledcAttachPin(FAN_PIN, PWM_CHANNEL);

  // Start with fan off
  ledcWrite(PWM_CHANNEL, 0);
}

void loop() {
  // Ramp fan speed up
  for (int duty = 0; duty <= 255; duty += 5) {
    ledcWrite(PWM_CHANNEL, duty);
    delay(40);
  }

  // Hold full speed for a bit
  delay(2000);

  // Ramp fan speed down
  for (int duty = 255; duty >= 0; duty -= 5) {
    ledcWrite(PWM_CHANNEL, duty);
    delay(40);
  }

  // Fan off for a while
  ledcWrite(PWM_CHANNEL, 0);
  delay(2000);
}

Libraries needed: - No extra libraries; just the standard ESP32 Arduino core (which provides ledcSetup, ledcAttachPin, and ledcWrite).

You can replace the ramping logic with any temperature‑based control, PID controller, or manual control via web UI, MQTT, etc.

docs.title: Battery Spring Contacts Set - CN003
docs.text: Assorted battery spring contacts for building or repairing battery holders and packs. Includes 18650 spring plates and AA/AAA coil + plate contacts. Useful for quick prototypes, low-cost holders, and custom enclosures.

docs.title: Links

docs.title: Specifications (typical)
docs.text:
• Material: nickel-plated steel spring/plate
  • Types: 18650 single-contact positive/negative plates; AA/AAA coil + flat plate
  • Pitch/spacing: depends on cell size (18650 Ø18 mm; AA Ø14 mm; AAA Ø10 mm)
  • Mounting: solder tabs; can be spot-welded to nickel strip for packs

docs.text:

  • For packs: prefer spot-welding to nickel strip; avoid heating cells directly.
  • Ensure firm mechanical compression for reliable contact.

  • Heat: do not solder directly to cell terminals; risk of damage.
  • Spring sag: long springs add resistance and can loosen; design for compression.

docs.title: 8-pin DIP IC socket - CN004
docs.text:
Simple through-hole socket for 8-pin DIP (dual in-line package) ICs. Use it whenever you want to be able to swap an 8-pin IC (op-amp, timer, small MCU, etc.) without resoldering, or to protect delicate IC legs from heat and mechanical stress.

Because this is just a mechanical connector, there is no electrical behaviour beyond passing each pin straight through.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: Not typically provided for simple IC sockets (mechanical connector only).

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• 8-pin DIP socket (accepts standard 8-pin DIP ICs)
  • 2.54 mm pin pitch (0.1")
  • Standard 7.62 mm (300 mil) row spacing for DIP-8 IC packages
  • Through-hole, solder-type legs for mounting on perfboard or PCBs
  • Each pin is a straight one-to-one connection (no internal circuitry)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text: Not applicable – this is a passive mechanical socket. Each socket position simply connects the IC leg on the top side to the corresponding pin on the bottom side.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
• Solder the 8 pins into your PCB or perfboard where the DIP-8 IC would normally go.
  • Route each pad/pin to your circuit as if the IC were soldered directly.
  • When finished, insert the 8-pin IC into the socket, matching the notch or dot on the IC with the notch on the socket and silkscreen.

From the ESP32 (or any other MCU) point of view, there is no difference between an IC in a socket and one soldered directly.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Orientation: Always align the IC’s notch or dot with the socket’s notch and the PCB silkscreen to avoid reversed connections.
  • Mechanical stress: Don’t lever the IC out using a single side – gently pry from both ends to avoid bending pins.
  • Soldering: Avoid excessive soldering heat that could soften or deform the plastic body.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
No code example is needed – this is a purely mechanical connector. Just design your circuit for a normal 8-pin DIP IC footprint and place this socket there so you can plug/unplug the IC easily.

docs.title: BME280 / BMP280 — ENV001
docs.text: Aliases: Bosch BME280 / BMP280 (common breakouts: CJMCU, GY-BME280, GY-BMP280) Category: ENV

docs.title: Quick Facts
docs.text:
• BME280: Temperature, Humidity, Pressure.
  • BMP280: Temperature, Pressure (no humidity).
  • Buses: I²C or SPI • I²C addrs: 0x76 (default) / 0x77 (SDO high)
  • Voltage (chip): 1.71–3.6 V • Most breakouts accept 3.3 V (some are 5 V-tolerant via onboard LDO/level shifting).
  • Typical accuracy: T ±1.0 °C (can be improved with calibration), RH ±3% (BME280), Pressure ±1 hPa.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Tutorial: Random Nerd Tutorials
  • Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheets:
    • BME280 (Bosch)
    • BMP280 (Bosch)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
• VIN / 3V3 (power), GND
  • SDA, SCL (I²C)
  • SDO (I²C addr select): low→0x76, high→0x77
  • CSB, SCK, SDI, SDO (SPI mode on some boards)

Many boards expose both I²C and SPI; leave CSB high for I²C. For I²C on ESP32, default pins are GPIO21 (SDA) / GPIO22 (SCL) unless you choose others.

docs.title: Wiring (ESP32 • I²C)
docs.text:
• VIN → 3.3 V, GND → GND
  • SDA → GPIO 21, SCL → GPIO 22
  • If you have bus errors on long cables, drop I²C speed (e.g., 100 kHz) and use ~4.7 kΩ pull-ups to 3.3 V.

(Credit: Random Nerd Tutorials)

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Clone confusion: Many boards marked “BME280” actually carry BMP280 (no RH). Check chip ID: BME280 = 0x60, BMP280 = 0x58.
  • Address mismatch: If 0x76 fails, try 0x77 (tie SDO high or use the solder-jumper).
  • Voltage: Some cheap boards are 3.3 V only (no regulator/level shifter). Feeding 5 V can kill the sensor—inspect the PCB.
  • Condensation: For accurate RH, avoid mounting where moisture condenses; add a small vented enclosure and allow airflow.
  • Humidity reads 0 or NAN: You likely have a BMP280 or a mislabeled breakout; check the chip ID.

docs.title: How to use (Arduino • auto-detect BME vs BMP)
docs.text:
// ESP32 + BME280/BMP280 (I2C) — auto-detect, prints RH only if BME280
// Libraries (Library Manager): Adafruit BME280, Adafruit BMP280, Adafruit Unified Sensor
#include <Wire.h>
#include <Adafruit_BME280.h>
#include <Adafruit_BMP280.h>

#define SDA_PIN 21
#define SCL_PIN 22

Adafruit_BME280 bme;   // for BME280
Adafruit_BMP280 bmp;   // for BMP280
bool hasBME = false;
bool hasBMP = false;

bool beginAt(uint8_t addr) {
  if (bme.begin(addr)) { hasBME = true; return true; }
  if (bmp.begin(addr)) { hasBMP = true; return true; }
  return false;
}

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  Wire.begin(SDA_PIN, SCL_PIN);     // you can also Wire.setClock(100000);

  // Try 0x76 then 0x77
  if (!beginAt(0x76) && !beginAt(0x77)) {
    Serial.println("Sensor not found at 0x76/0x77. Check wiring/address.");
    while (1) delay(10);
  }

  if (hasBME) {
    // Oversampling settings (balance noise vs. power/latency)
    bme.setSampling(Adafruit_BME280::MODE_NORMAL,
                    Adafruit_BME280::SAMPLING_X2,   // Temp
                    Adafruit_BME280::SAMPLING_X2,   // Hum
                    Adafruit_BME280::SAMPLING_X4,   // Pressure
                    Adafruit_BME280::FILTER_X4,
                    Adafruit_BME280::STANDBY_MS_125);
    Serial.println("BME280 ready (T/RH/Pressure).");
  } else {
    bmp.setSampling(Adafruit_BMP280::MODE_NORMAL,
                    Adafruit_BMP280::SAMPLING_X2,   // Temp
                    Adafruit_BMP280::SAMPLING_X4,   // Pressure
                    Adafruit_BMP280::FILTER_X4,
                    Adafruit_BMP280::STANDBY_MS_125);
    Serial.println("BMP280 ready (T/Pressure).");
  }
}

float seaLevelhPa = 1013.25;  // set to your local sea-level pressure for altitude calc

void loop() {
  if (hasBME) {
    float t = bme.readTemperature();           // °C
    float h = bme.readHumidity();              // %
    float p = bme.readPressure() / 100.0F;     // hPa
    float alt = bme.readAltitude(seaLevelhPa); // meters
    Serial.printf("T=%.2f°C  RH=%.1f%%  P=%.2f hPa  Alt≈%.1f m\n", t, h, p, alt);
  } else {
    float t = bmp.readTemperature();           // °C
    float p = bmp.readPressure() / 100.0F;     // hPa
    float alt = bmp.readAltitude(seaLevelhPa); // meters
    Serial.printf("T=%.2f°C  P=%.2f hPa  Alt≈%.1f m\n", t, p, alt);
  }
  delay(1000);
}

docs.title: LDR 5528 - ENV002
docs.text:
A 5528-series light-dependent resistor (LDR) is a simple cadmium-sulfide (CdS) photoresistor. Its resistance drops as the light level increases, which makes it ideal as a very cheap, analog ambient light sensor for things like night-lights, auto-dimming displays, and “it’s dark / it’s bright” detection.

This specific GL5528-style part is a 5 mm epoxy-encapsulated LDR. In typical conditions it measures on the order of tens of kilo-ohms in moderate light and rises to around a megaohm in the dark, so it works very well in a classic voltage-divider configuration with a fixed resistor and an ESP32 ADC pin.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: PDF – GL5528 Photoresistor
  • Tutorial: ESP32 – Light Sensor (esp32io.com)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
Approximate characteristics for a typical GL5528/5528 LDR:

  • Package: 5 mm CdS photoresistor (2-pin, through-hole)
  • Light resistance (bright, ~10 lux): ~10–20 kΩ
  • Dark resistance (0 lux): ≥ 1 MΩ
  • Maximum DC voltage: ~150 V
  • Maximum power dissipation: ~100 mW (at 25 °C)
  • Spectral peak: ~540 nm (green)
  • Response time: tens of milliseconds (order of 20–50 ms)
  • Operating temperature: roughly −30 °C to +70 °C

These values are not precision-guaranteed for every random AliExpress batch, but they’re good ballpark numbers for choosing divider resistors and thresholds.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
This is just the bare 2‑lead LDR component, not a module, so there is no real “pinout”:

  • Pin 1: LDR terminal (no polarity)
  • Pin 2: LDR terminal (no polarity)

You use it exactly like a variable resistor. Orientation does not matter. There is no I²C/SPI address or digital interface – you must build a simple resistor divider to read it with an ADC.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
The classic way to use an LDR with an ESP32 is as a voltage divider:

  1. Pick a fixed resistor value, typically in the same order of magnitude as the LDR in the mid-light range, e.g. 10 kΩ.
  2. Connect one LDR leg to 3.3 V.
  3. Connect the other LDR leg to:
  4. the ESP32 analog input pin, e.g. GPIO 34 (ADC1_CH6), and
  5. one side of the fixed resistor (10 kΩ) at the same node.
  6. Connect the other side of the fixed resistor to GND.

That node between LDR and fixed resistor goes to the ESP32 ADC input. As light increases, the LDR resistance drops, changing the voltage at the ADC pin.

Notes:

  • Use only ADC-capable pins on the ESP32 (e.g. 32–39 on most dev boards).
  • Keep the divider tied to 3.3 V, never 5 V, to avoid overstressing the ESP32.
  • If needed, you can add a small capacitor (e.g. 0.1 µF) from the ADC node to GND to filter noise and ESP32 ADC sampling glitches.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Not a precision lux sensor – good for thresholds (“dark vs bright”), not for accurate lux readings.
  • Device-to-device variation is large; you may need to tune thresholds per build.
  • Non-linear and slowish response compared to photodiodes/phototransistors – not suitable for fast light changes or data links.
  • Contains CdS (cadmium sulfide); some regions have restrictions on cadmium-containing devices.
  • Always use it in a divider, not directly across 3.3 V into an ADC pin.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Simple example for an ESP32 (Arduino framework) reading the LDR via a voltage divider and turning an LED on when it’s dark.

// Simple ESP32 LDR example
// LDR + 10k resistor in divider:
// 3V3 --- LDR --- ADC_PIN --- 10k --- GND

const int LDR_PIN = 34;     // ADC-capable pin
const int LED_PIN = 2;      // Built-in LED on many ESP32 dev boards

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  pinMode(LED_PIN, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
  int raw = analogRead(LDR_PIN);   // 0..4095 on most ESP32 boards

  // Simple threshold: adjust to taste
  bool isDark = (raw < 1500);

  digitalWrite(LED_PIN, isDark ? HIGH : LOW);

  Serial.print("LDR raw = ");
  Serial.print(raw);
  Serial.print(" -> ");
  Serial.println(isDark ? "Dark" : "Bright");

  delay(200);
}

No special libraries are required – just the standard Arduino core for ESP32. You can refine this by:

  • Mapping the ADC value to a “percentage light”.
  • Implementing hysteresis for stable switching.
  • Sampling and averaging to reduce noise.

docs.title: TTP223 - IO001
docs.text: A tiny one‑key capacitive touch switch module based on the TTP223 IC. Acts like a digital push‑button: when you touch the pad it toggles or holds the output depending on solder‑pad settings. Ideal as a human‑touch input for ESP32 projects (UI buttons, lamps, mode selectors). Power it at 3.3 V when connecting directly to ESP32 GPIO.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: PDF
  • Tutorial: ESP32 + TTP223 (Instructables)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Module size: 15 mm × 11 mm
  • Supply voltage (VCC): 2.5–5.5 V
  • Output: digital TTL (follows VCC), active HIGH or LOW per configuration
  • Modes (A/B solder pads):
  • A=0, B=0 → momentary, output HIGH while touched
  • A=1, B=0 → toggle (self‑latch), output HIGH toggles on each touch
  • A=0, B=1 → momentary, output LOW while touched
  • A=1, B=1 → toggle (self‑latch), output LOW toggles on each touch

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
• VCC — 2.5–5.5 V supply (use 3.3 V for ESP32 direct GPIO)
  • OUT — Digital output (HIGH/LOW per mode)
  • GND — Ground
  • Pads A/B — Solder‑jumpers selecting momentary vs toggle and active‑high vs active‑low (see table above).

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
ESP32 (3.3 V): - VCC → 3V3 - GND → GND - OUT → any GPIO (e.g., GPIO 25)

No extra resistors are required on typical boards; the module conditions the signal. If you enable the ESP32's internal pull‑down or pull‑up, adjust logic accordingly.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• If you power the module at 5 V, OUT will be 5 V and not 3.3 V‑safe → either power at 3.3 V or level‑shift before an ESP32 GPIO.
  • Long leads, moisture, or noisy grounds can cause false triggers—keep wiring short and add decoupling (e.g., 0.1 µF across VCC–GND) if needed.
  • Touch pad sensitivity varies by board and environment; avoid mounting behind thick plastic or metal without testing.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Minimal example (Arduino IDE on ESP32). Assumes A=0,B=0 (momentary, active‑HIGH) and OUT on GPIO 25:

// TTP223 -> ESP32 example
// VCC=3V3, GND=GND, OUT=GPIO25
const int TOUCH_PIN = 25;

void setup() {
  pinMode(TOUCH_PIN, INPUT);      // or INPUT_PULLDOWN if you prefer
  Serial.begin(115200);
}

void loop() {
  int touched = digitalRead(TOUCH_PIN); // HIGH while finger is touching
  if (touched) {
    Serial.println("Touch!");
  }
  delay(10);
}

docs.title: KY-040 - IO003
docs.text: Compact incremental rotary encoder module (usually built around an ALPS EC11 encoder) with an integrated push‑button. Use it as a UI knob to scroll menus, set values, or navigate—unlike a potentiometer it rotates continuously and outputs quadrature pulses (CLK/DT) to indicate steps and direction.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: EC11 (typical encoder used on KY‑040 boards)
  • Tutorial: uPesy – Rotary Encoder on ESP32

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Steps per revolution: ~20 (detents), incremental (quadrature A/B)
  • Push‑button: momentary, active‑low on SW
  • Supply voltage: works at 3.3–5 V (many KY‑040 boards include pull‑ups to VCC – power at 3.3 V for ESP32‑safe logic)
  • Typical encoder family: ALPS EC11 (variants exist)
  • Shaft length: ~20 mm (per listing)

Notes: Some vendors advertise “20 pulses/turn”; others “20 detents”. Expect minor variation between batches. If exact counts matter, measure on your unit.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
• CLK – Channel A (interrupt‑friendly GPIO)
  • DT – Channel B
  • SW – Push‑button output (active‑low)
  • + / VCC – Module supply (use 3.3 V with ESP32)
  • GND – Ground

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
• Power VCC → 3.3 V, GND → GND (recommended with ESP32 to avoid 5 V logic).
  • CLK → GPIO 25 (any input pin; interrupt‑capable helps)
  • DT → GPIO 26
  • SW → GPIO 27 (enable input pull‑up if your board lacks one)

Most KY‑040 boards already have ~10 kΩ pull‑ups to VCC on CLK/DT/SW. If so, do not enable internal pull‑ups; instead ensure the board is powered at 3.3 V so logic levels are safe.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Bounce: mechanical bounce causes false counts; do simple edge filtering/debouncing in code.
  • 5 V warning: Many modules pull up to VCC—if powered at 5 V, signals will be 5 V and not ESP32‑safe. Use 3.3 V.
  • Wiring length: long leads pick up noise; keep short or add small caps (e.g., 0.01–0.1 µF) if needed.
  • Count per detent varies by encoder variant; treat counts as approximate.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Below is a minimal Arduino sketch for ESP32 using an interrupt on CLK and reading DT to determine direction. The push‑button SW is debounced in software.

// KY-040 on ESP32 minimal example
// CLK -> GPIO25, DT -> GPIO26, SW -> GPIO27, VCC -> 3V3, GND -> GND

volatile long encoderCount = 0;
const int PIN_CLK = 25;
const int PIN_DT  = 26;
const int PIN_SW  = 27;

volatile int lastCLK = 0;
unsigned long lastButtonMs = 0;

void IRAM_ATTR onCLK() {
  int clkState = digitalRead(PIN_CLK);
  int dtState  = digitalRead(PIN_DT);
  // Count on rising edge only
  if (clkState == HIGH) {
    if (dtState == LOW) encoderCount++;  // CW
    else                encoderCount--;  // CCW
  }
}

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  pinMode(PIN_CLK, INPUT); // leave INPUT if board has external pull-ups
  pinMode(PIN_DT,  INPUT);
  pinMode(PIN_SW,  INPUT_PULLUP); // many KY-040s have pull-up; INPUT_PULLUP is fine too
  attachInterrupt(digitalPinToInterrupt(PIN_CLK), onCLK, CHANGE);
}

void loop() {
  static long lastReported = 0;
  if (encoderCount != lastReported) {
    long v = encoderCount;
    lastReported = v;
    Serial.printf("Count: %ld\n", v);
  }

  // Simple button read with debounce
  unsigned long now = millis();
  if (digitalRead(PIN_SW) == LOW && (now - lastButtonMs) > 50) {
    lastButtonMs = now;
    Serial.println("Button press!");
  }
}

Libraries: none required. For advanced handling (acceleration, better debouncing), try Encoder (Paul Stoffregen) or AiEsp32RotaryEncoder.

docs.title: LM386 Audio Amplifier Module - OT001
docs.text: Compact mono audio power amplifier board built around the LM386 IC. Good for adding a small speaker to projects. It runs from 5–12 V and can provide modest volume for 8 Ω/4 Ω speakers. Typical voltage gain is 20 (no parts) and can be increased up to 200 with a cap between pins 1 and 8 (on most boards this is pre‑wired). Use it when you just need simple, low‑power audio without I²S.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: Texas Instruments – LM386 PDF
  • Tutorial: ESP32 audio player using LM386 (CircuitDigest)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Supply voltage (V_S): 5–12 V (module rating from listing); LM386 IC operates from about 4–12 V per datasheet
  • Voltage gain: 20 by default (pins 1 & 8 open); up to 200 with external cap between pins 1 & 8
  • Output: mono speaker driver (suitable for small 8 Ω / 4 Ω speakers)
  • On‑board input gain/volume trimmer is common on many modules (varies by board)
  • Typical decoupling on board; add extra bulk capacitance if supply is noisy

(Numbers above are conservative summaries from the AliExpress listing and the TI datasheet. Exact power output depends on supply voltage, load, and the specific module.)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
Most LM386 boards expose: - VCC – 5–12 V supply - GND – Ground - IN (or AUDIO IN) – AC‑coupled audio input (from ESP32 DAC or other source) - SPK+, SPK− – Speaker output to small 8 Ω/4 Ω speaker

Board silkscreens vary; check your PCB for exact labels.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text: Example with ESP32 DAC (GPIO25) and 5 V supply: - Power: 5 V to VCC on the module; GND common between ESP32 and module. - Input: ESP32 GPIO25 (DAC1) → (optional 10 µF series capacitor, + toward ESP32) → IN on the module. Tie IN GND/GND to ESP32 GND. - Speaker: Connect small speaker to SPK+/SPK−. - Decoupling: Add 100 µF electrolytic across VCC–GND near the module plus a 100 nF ceramic close to the pins.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Don’t power the module from the ESP32’s 3.3 V regulator—use 5–12 V. Share ground.
  • Keep input leads short; long wires pick up hum and can cause oscillation.
  • High gain can make it noisy; reduce gain (remove/bypass the 1–8 cap) or lower input level.
  • The output is for a small speaker; it’s not a line‑out nor a high‑power amp.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Minimal Arduino example: generate a 1 kHz tone on DAC1 (GPIO25) and feed it to the module.

// ESP32 + LM386 demo: 1 kHz tone on DAC1 (GPIO25)
#include <Arduino.h>

const int dacPin = 25;        // DAC1
const int sampleRate = 20000; // 20 kHz
const float freq = 1000.0f;   // 1 kHz
const uint8_t amplitude = 120; // 0..255 (keep moderate)
const uint8_t offset = 128;    // center for DAC

void setup() { }
void loop() {
  static uint32_t n = 0;
  float t = (float)n / sampleRate;
  uint8_t v = offset + (uint8_t)(amplitude * sinf(2.0f * PI * freq * t));
  dacWrite(dacPin, v);
  n++;
  // delay to set sample rate
  delayMicroseconds(1000000 / sampleRate);
}

Libraries: none (uses built‑in dacWrite). For better audio, consider I²S DAC/amps.

docs.title: Key lock switch - OT002
docs.text: A small panel‑mount key lock switch often sold as model S1201. It’s a mechanical, maintained switch that requires a key to turn between two positions, making it ideal for lockout/enable functions, parental/maintenance overrides, or arming/disarming features. Many S1201 variants allow the key to be removed in both positions ("double‑side pull‑out"). If you just need a secure human input (not a powered lock/solenoid), this is likely the right part.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet: Example – similar key lock switch
  • Tutorial: ESP32 switch basics (ESP32IO)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Form factor: panel‑mount, approx. Ø12 mm mounting hole (bezel/stem sized for 12 mm panels)
  • Typical rating (per listings): 0.5 A @ 250 VAC, 1 A @ 125 VAC
  • Operation: 2‑position, maintained (key turns between two positions)
  • Key feature: Key removable in both positions on many variants (“double‑side pull‑out”)
  • Contacts: usually 2 terminals (switch closes in ON position). Some variants may differ.
  • Material: stainless/metal body; includes 2 keys
  • Intended use: low‑voltage signal or AC mains switching (observe rating; do not route mains anywhere near an ESP32 board)

Note: S1201 is a market/model label used by multiple vendors; exact dimensions and terminal layout can vary slightly by batch/vendor.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text: This is a plain mechanical switch (no I2C/SPI/UART). Most pieces have two lugs: - Term1 and Term2: the switch connects these in the ON position; open in the OFF position. - Some variants may mark C (common) and NO (normally open). Use a multimeter to confirm before wiring.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
For use as an ESP32 digital input (low‑voltage only):

  • Connect one terminal to an ESP32 GPIO (e.g., GPIO 23).
  • Connect the other terminal to GND.
  • In code, enable the pin’s internal pull‑up so the input reads HIGH when open and LOW when the key is turned (closed to GND).

Schematic (text): 

ESP32 GPIO ---[switch]--- GND
(Use INPUT_PULLUP in software)

Do not put mains voltage on the same switch if you also connect it to an ESP32. If you need mains isolation, use a separate mains‑rated switch or an optocoupler/relay interface.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Debounce: Mechanical switches bounce. Debounce in software (or add an RC network if needed).
  • Key removal: Many units allow key removal in both positions—design your UX accordingly.
  • Variant drift: Terminal layout and travel can vary between sellers; verify with a multimeter.
  • Not weatherproof: Exposed lock cylinders can corrode outdoors without protection.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
Arduino (ESP32) example – read as a digital input with internal pull‑up:

// Key switch on GPIO 23, wired to GND when ON
const int KEY_PIN = 23;

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  pinMode(KEY_PIN, INPUT_PULLUP);  // enable internal pull-up
}

bool readKey() {
  // LOW means switch closed to GND (key in ON position)
  static uint32_t lastChange = 0;
  static bool lastState = true;
  bool raw = digitalRead(KEY_PIN);     // HIGH=open, LOW=closed
  // simple debounce
  if (millis() - lastChange > 20 && raw != lastState) {
    lastChange = millis();
    lastState = raw;
  }
  return lastState == LOW;             // true when ON
}

void loop() {
  if (readKey()) {
    Serial.println("Key: ON");
  } else {
    Serial.println("Key: OFF");
  }
  delay(200);
}

docs.title: 3296W Trimmer Potentiometers — IO101
docs.text: Aliases: Bourns‑style 3296W (multiturn cermet trim pot, top‑adjust) Package: 3/8″ square, sealed cermet (through‑hole)

docs.title: Quick Facts
docs.text:
• Adjustment: 25‑turn, top‑adjust (slot).
  • Power rating (series): 0.5 W at 70 °C (derates to 0 W at 125 °C).
  • Resistance tolerance (series): ±10% (typical for many 3296 variants).
  • Tempco (series): typically ±100 ppm/°C.
  • Terminals: 3 pins in‑line — 1 (end), 2 (wiper), 3 (end). Rotation is clockwise to increase resistance between wiper and terminal 1 per series drawing.

Working voltage is limited by power: \(V_{max} \approx \sqrt{P_{rated}\cdot R}\). Keep the wiper current low and stay within series ratings.

docs.title: What’s in this kit (26 pcs, 13 values × 2 each)
docs.text: 100 Ω, 200 Ω, 500 Ω, 1 kΩ, 2 kΩ, 5 kΩ, 10 kΩ, 20 kΩ, 50 kΩ, 100 kΩ, 200 kΩ, 500 kΩ, 1 MΩ (all 3296W form factor).

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Datasheet (series): Bourns 3296 Trimpot
  • General note: This kit is a clone/compatible set; mechanical and most electrical characteristics follow the 3296 series norms, but minor differences can exist across vendors.

docs.title: Pinout & Orientation
docs.text: • 1 – End, 2 – Wiper, 3 – End (inline). The 3296W variant is top‑adjust; 3296X is side‑adjust (same electrical function).

docs.title: Typical uses
docs.text:
• Calibrating sensor bridges and op‑amp gains/offsets
  • Setting thresholds (comparators), RC timing trims
  • Creating a voltage divider for a microcontroller ADC (e.g., ESP32)

docs.title: Wiring example (ESP32 ADC)
docs.text:
Voltage divider (recommended): - 3.3 V → pin 1, GND → pin 3, ADC input → pin 2 (wiper) - ESP32 reads 0–3.3 V as 0–4095 (12‑bit). The ESP32 ADC is somewhat non‑linear; for precision, apply calibration or a LUT.

// ESP32 + 3296W as a simple ADC knob (Arduino IDE)
// Connect: 1→3.3V, 3→GND, 2 (wiper) → GPIO34 (ADC1_CH6)
const int ADC_PIN = 34;

void setup() {
  Serial.begin(115200);
  analogReadResolution(12);      // 0..4095
  // analogSetPinAttenuation(ADC_PIN, ADC_11db); // optional
}

void loop() {
  int raw = analogRead(ADC_PIN);
  float v = (raw / 4095.0f) * 3.3f;  // approx conversion
  Serial.printf("raw=%d  ~V=%.3f\n", raw, v);
  delay(200);
}

docs.title: Notes & gotchas
docs.text:
• Power limit: Don’t drop significant voltage at high resistance with appreciable current—check \(P=I^2R\) and \(V^2/R\).
  • Wiper as output: Avoid large wiper current (use as a divider feeding a high‑impedance input).
  • Adjustment range: 25‑turn gives fine control; if you reach an end‑stop, reverse a few turns—don’t force it.
  • Variant naming: 3296W = top adjust; 3296X = side adjust (mechanical variant). Electrical ratings are shared across the 3296 series.

docs.title: Axial ferrite beads 3.5×8/9×0.8 - PA002
docs.text:
Small axial ferrite beads used as simple EMI filters on power or signal lines. You slide the bead over a lead or wire to add impedance at high frequency, helping to tame noisy modules, long sensor cables, or wires going in and out of your project enclosure.

They are generic unbranded parts from Javino; use them whenever you want a cheap way to reduce high‑frequency noise without changing your PCB.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Where to buy: AliExpress
  • Tutorial: Choosing and Using Ferrite Beads (AllAboutCircuits)

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
From the AliExpress listing (generic ferrite cores):

  • Type: axial ferrite bead / inductor bead
  • Quantity: ~50 pcs per lot
  • Outer diameter (OD): 3.5 mm
  • Inner diameter (wire hole): 0.8 mm
  • Height (length along the wire): 8–9 mm
  • Material: ferrite core
  • Color: may vary between batches (image is illustrative only)

There is no guaranteed inductance or impedance curve provided for this generic assortment – treat them as “good enough” EMI beads rather than precision components.

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
Not applicable – these are bare beads with no pins or markings.

Usage is purely mechanical:

  • Slide the bead over a wire or component lead.
  • Optionally loop the wire through the bead more than once to increase the effective impedance at high frequency.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text:
Typical ways to use these beads with an ESP32 (or any MCU):

  1. On a noisy peripheral’s supply line

  2. Put the bead in series with the V+ wire going to a noisy module (e.g. small DC motor driver, relay board, etc.).

  3. On the ESP32 side of the bead, place a decoupling capacitor (e.g. 100 nF, possibly plus a larger electrolytic) from V+ to GND.

  4. This forms a simple low‑pass filter: the bead resists high‑frequency noise, and the capacitor shunts it to ground.

  5. On long sensor cables

  6. Thread the sensor cable’s power (and optionally signal) conductor through a bead near the board end.

  7. This can help reduce RF noise picked up by long wires, improving ADC readings or avoiding random resets.

  8. On USB or power leads

  9. You can slide a bead over the 5 V feed to a small board as a basic EMI suppression measure.

  10. For better effect, loop the wire through the bead multiple times if the geometry allows.

Because these are loose beads, you normally use them on flying leads or you solder the wire+bead assembly into a through‑hole footprint on a PCB.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Not a precision inductor: These beads are for EMI suppression, not for tuned LC filters or precise inductance values.
  • Frequency‑dependent: They mainly affect high‑frequency noise (RF range). They will not fix low‑frequency ripple or sagging power rails.
  • No specified current rating: As generic parts, there is no guaranteed current spec. For small ESP32‑scale projects they are usually fine, but avoid using them in high‑current paths without testing.
  • Assortment variability: Dimensions and ferrite mix may vary slightly between batches; don’t rely on exact performance.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
There is no code required – these beads are purely hardware components.

General usage pattern:

  1. Identify a noisy or sensitive line (e.g. 5 V feeding a motor driver, long sensor cable, etc.).
  2. Cut that line and insert the bead in series by sliding it over the wire or lead.
  3. Add a decoupling capacitor on the MCU side of the bead when filtering power.
  4. Test the circuit (e.g. check for fewer resets, less noise on ADC readings, less EMI).

You can combine these beads with good layout and grounding practices for best results.

docs.title: Schottky Diode Kit (8 Values) — PS101
docs.text:
Includes: 1N4148, 1N4007, 1N5819, 1N5399, 1N5408, 1N5822, FR107, FR207 Category: PS (Power / protection parts) AliExpress listing: 8 Values 100PCS Diode Kit

What this kit is for: A small set that covers signal switching, power rectification, low-loss Schottky needs, and fast recovery for PWM/switching supplies. You reach for a diode whenever you need current to flow only one way, to turn AC into DC, to protect against reverse polarity, or to safely absorb energy from an inductive load (motors, relays, solenoids).

docs.title: Quick Selection Cheatsheet
docs.text:
• Relay/solenoid flyback @ 5–24 V: 1N4007 (OK), FR107 (better for fast PWM), 1N5819/1N5822 (Schottky, low drop, cool).
  • Motor freewheel (PWM): FR107/FR207 or 1N5822 (Schottky 3 A). Avoid slow 1N4007 at high PWM.
  • Reverse‑polarity input protection (low current): 1N5819 (≤1 A) or 1N5822 (≤3 A) for low loss; 1N4007 okay if drop isn’t critical.
  • Bridge rectifier for small adapters (≤1 A): 1N4007 (x4). For 1.5–3 A use 1N5399/1N5408 (x4).
  • Signal steering / logic / clamp: 1N4148 (fast small‑signal).
  • High‑voltage rectification: 1N4007 (1000 V), 1N5399 (1.5 A • 1000 V), 1N5408 (3 A • 1000 V), FR107/FR207 (fast • 1000 V).

docs.title: What’s in the kit (specs & typical uses)
docs.text:
Part Type If rating Vr (V_RRM) Vf @ rated If Speed (approx) Typical uses 1N4148 Small‑signal switching 150 mA 100 V ~1.0 V @ 10 mA Very fast (ns) Logic steering, clamp, small signal paths, RC discharge, speed‑ups 1N4007 Rectifier (standard) 1 A 1000 V ~0.95 V @ 1 A Slow (µs) Bridges up to ~1 A, DC input protection, relay flyback (non‑PWM) 1N5819 Schottky 1 A 40 V ~0.2–0.45 V Fast (ns–tens ns) Low‑drop reverse protection, buck/boost catch diode ≤1 A, motor flyback at low V 1N5399 Rectifier (standard) 1.5 A 1000 V ~0.95–1.1 V Slow (µs) Bridges/regulation around 1–1.5 A, chargers 1N5408 Rectifier (standard) 3 A 1000 V ~1.0–1.2 V Slow (µs) Mains bridge rectifier, 2–3 A loads 1N5822 Schottky 3 A 40 V ~0.35–0.55 V Fast (ns–tens ns) Low‑loss high‑current catch diode, reverse protection up to ~3 A FR107 Fast‑recovery 1 A 1000 V ~0.95 V @ 1 A Fast (~500 ns) PWM freewheel, SMPS secondary, better flyback for high‑speed switching FR207 Fast‑recovery 2 A 1000 V ~1.0–1.2 V Fast (~500 ns) Like FR107 but more current; motor/solenoid PWM, beefier catch diode

Notes: - If = average forward current at 25 °C with adequate heatsinking. Peak/surge currents are higher but short‑lived. - Schottkys have low Vf and no reverse recovery “tail”, but higher reverse leakage that rises with temperature. - “Vr (V_RRM)” is the maximum repetitive reverse voltage; stay well below with margin (see sizing, below).

docs.title: 1) Relay/solenoid “flyback” protection
docs.text:
When you turn off an inductor, it tries to keep current flowing and can spike your MOSFET/MCU. Place the diode across the coil, cathode to +, anode to −.

+V ----[coil]----+----> to driver
                 |
                 | |<|  diode (cathode at +V)
                 |
GND -------------+
  • Slow switching (on/off): 1N4007 is fine.
  • Fast PWM drive: choose FR107/FR207 or Schottky (1N5819/1N5822) to reduce recovery losses and coil “ring”.

docs.title: 2) DC input reverse‑polarity protection
docs.text:
Put a diode in series with the + input (simple) or across the input with a fuse (lower drop in normal operation with Schottky + fuse).

  • Series diode: 1N5819 (≤1 A) or 1N5822 (≤3 A) to minimize voltage drop/heat.
  • Shunt + fuse: 1N5408 for robust sacrifice‑mode (blows fuse on reverse).

docs.title: 3) Power OR‑ing (choose the highest supply, block back‑feed)
docs.text:
• Low‑current: two 1N5819 from each source to the load.
  • Higher current: 1N5822 pair. (For ultra‑low loss, ideal‑diode MOSFETs are better, but diodes are simple and robust.)

docs.title: 4) Bridge rectifier (AC → DC)
docs.text: Use four identical diodes. Size by load current and reverse voltage (Vr ≥ 2× Vac_rms × 1.414). - Up to ~0.7–0.8 A: 1N4007 bridge. - ~1–1.3 A: 1N5399. - ~2–3 A: 1N5408.

docs.title: 5) Buck/boost “catch” diode
docs.text:
• Up to ~1 A: 1N5819 (Schottky).
  • Up to ~3 A: 1N5822. Avoid slow 1N400x here; switching losses and reverse recovery heating will be large.

docs.title: 6) Signal‑level tasks
docs.text:
• Clamp small transients, level steering, RC discharge, SPI/I²C speed‑up networks: 1N4148.
  • For ESD‑class surges use TVS diodes (not in this kit).

docs.title: Polarity & Symbols
docs.text:
• Stripe = Cathode (K), no stripe = Anode (A). Current flows A → K.
  • On schematics, the triangle‑bar symbol (for diodes in general) points from A to K. For Schottky, the symbol looks similar but may have an ‘S’ or unique style.

docs.title: Sizing Rules of Thumb
docs.text:
1. Reverse voltage margin: choose Vr ≥ 2× the highest DC you’ll see (or ≥ 3× the peak of any ringing spikes).
  2. Current: the average forward current should be ≤ 50–70 % of the diode’s rated If at your ambient.
  3. Vf & heat: power loss ≈ Vf × I_avg. Schottky saves heat at low voltages.
  4. Speed matters: for PWM/switching supplies use Schottky or fast‑recovery. Slow 1N400x diodes are fine for mains/low‑frequency rectification but run hot in switchers.
  5. Temperature: Schottky leakage rises with temperature; ensure reverse leakage × Vr doesn’t cause runaway in hot environments.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Wrong orientation destroys parts. Check the stripe (K).
  • Using 1N400x in high‑frequency circuits → heating and noise due to reverse recovery.
  • Schottky leakage can upset very low‑power systems when reversed; consider standard diodes if leakage matters.
  • Voltage spikes from inductors can exceed Vr; add RC snubbers or TVS if needed.
  • Bridge rectifiers drop about 2×Vf; ensure headroom for regulators.

docs.title: Multi-output linear power board - PS401
docs.text:
A small utility power board that takes a DC barrel input (center‑positive) or a 9 V battery clip and provides several fixed rails: 12 V (pass‑through from input), 9 V, 5 V, and 3.3 V, plus a USB‑A 5 V output. Rails are generated by linear regulators (e.g., 78xx/7805 and AMS1117‑3.3), not switch‑mode converters. Use it as a quick bench/desk supply to power prototypes and small modules when you need multiple voltages at once.

If you need high efficiency or >~few‑hundred‑mA on low rails, use a DC‑DC converter instead—this board will waste heat because it’s linear.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text:
• Inputs
    • DC‑in barrel jack (likely 5.5×2.1 mm, center‑positive). Practical input range ~7–12 V.
    • 9 V battery clip (for light loads).
  • Outputs
    • 12 V: pass‑through from DC‑in (no regulation other than input source).
    • 9 V: linear (typically 7809‑class).
    • 5 V: linear (typically 7805‑class) and mirrored to USB‑A port.
    • 3.3 V: linear (typically AMS1117‑3.3 or similar).
  • Controls & Indicators
    • ON/OFF slide switch; power LED.
    • Jumpers to route/select rails to the side header pins (labels near jumpers usually read 3.3V / 5V / 9V / 12V / GND).
  • Form factor
    • Through‑hole headers for tapping GND and a selected rail.
    • SOT‑223 regulator packages on board.

(Details like exact regulator models and maximum current vary by vendor; inspect your board markings if you need exact numbers.)

docs.title: Pinout & Addresses (common breakout labels)
docs.text:
• DC‑IN (barrel jack): center‑positive VIN.
  • 9 V clip: alternative input source.
  • USB‑A: 5 V output tied to the 5 V rail.
  • Header pins: GND + one jumper‑selected rail (3.3/5/9/12 V).
  • Switch: powers the board on/off.
  • LED: power indicator.

docs.title: Wiring
docs.text: For an ESP32 project: 1. Feed the board 7–12 V on the barrel jack (center‑positive) or connect a 9 V battery clip (light loads only). 2. Set the header jumper to 5 V (or 3.3 V if you must power 3.3 V‑only modules directly). 3. Connect GND from the board to GND on your ESP32. 4. Power your ESP32 via 5 V (recommended: into the 5V/VIN pin on dev boards) or use the USB‑A 5 V to feed a USB‑powered board. 5. Keep wiring short and watch regulator temperature if you draw sustained current.

docs.title: Gotchas
docs.text:
• Linear = heat. The larger the difference between VIN and Vout and the higher the load current, the hotter it gets.
  • Headroom required. Linear regulators need input above the target rail (e.g., 7805 needs ~7 V for a solid 5 V).
  • Do not back‑feed. Avoid powering the USB‑A input side or feeding 5 V back into the board.
  • 9 V batteries sag. Use only for light/short loads.
  • Common ground. Tie GNDs if you power other modules from different rails.

docs.title: How to use
docs.text:
This is a power board, so no code is required. Treat it as a small bench supply for prototypes. If you need USB‑C PD, buck/boost, or higher current, pick a DC‑DC module instead.
